div.head: The Author on her weak POEMS.

lg.l: GO, little Book, and take thy Rounds,
And if thou meet'st with Angry Frowns,
Then Blame thy Author, and her Quill,
For having of so little Skill.
But do not Blame her over much,
Because that she is one of such
Which counted is the weaker Sex,
And wanteth Skill thee to correct.
Kind Reader, though these Lines are few,
I pray do not them scorn to view.

div.head: A Word of Advice to the Female Sex.

lg.l: COme, Female-Sex, and Labour now apace,
And do not spend away your Day of Grace:
Our Souls let's value at a higher Rate,
And look about us, e'er it be too late.
For, Time being past, cannot re called be,
As by Experience daily we may see;
For as the Tree doth fall, so it shall Iye,
And so remain to all Eternity,
We do not know how soon there may appear
A Famine of God's blessed Word, most dear;
And that we may be forced for to fly
From Sea to Sea, after it's sweet Supply.
And yet there is another thing to fear,
We know not when to us Death will draw near,
And with a Stroke may send us hence away,
And suffer us no longer here to stay.
This juggling World hath us all round beset,
And she has spread out wide her charming Net,
Therefore let us be watchful, and take care,
That so we may escape her 'chanting Snare.

div.head: A few Meditations on the glorious Attributes of GOD.

lg.l: GOD's Attribute of Goodness is most great,
And he in Goodness is a God compleat;
There is no Man nor Angel doth it know,
It is a Fountain that doth Over-flow.
God's Attribute of Love, it hath no end,
It doth above all other Love transcend;
There is no Man nor Angel doth it know,
It is a Fountain which doth Over-flow.
God's Attribute of Mercy is so pure,
That now, and ever, still it will endure:
No Man, or Angel, never can it know,
It is a Fountain which doth Over-flow.
God's Attribute of Glory is so Bright,
That it doth Dazle all Beholder's Sight;
It is a Glory which doth so prevail,
The very Angels doth their Faces Vail.
God's Attribute of Knowledge is so high,
That he did Know, from all Eternity,
Adam would Fall, with his Posterity,
And so involve themselves in Misery.
God's Attribute of Wisdom, as we read,
By it the Heav'ns, and the Earth was made;
It is a Mystery which is so high,
The Angels they desire therein to pry.
God's Attribute of Justice none can let,
When he upon his Judgment-Seat shall sit,
To execute his Judgments Righteously,
'Twill make the Guilty Sinner loud to Cry.

l.hi: To speak of all God's Attributes,
it is for me too high
Which am an empty, barren Soul,
both withered and dry.

lg.l: I Empty am, Lord, Fill me with thy Grace,
And Barren too, here in my Spiritual Race:
Wither'd and Dry, thou know'st I am, O Lord,
Therefore to me thy Saving Grace afford.

div.head: THE FEMALES Legacy,
I. A Meditation on Adam in Paradice, and Fallen.

lg.l: THE Scripture doth declare to us,
the Mercy, Love, and Grace,
That God from all Eternity
upon mankind did place.
Adam he made a little lower
than Angels in degree,
And also gave to him a power,
with great Felicity.
All Creatures in the spacious World,
of him did stand in fear,
And Adam had witn them no trouble,
for he was void of care.
All living Substance in the world,
this Princely Man did see,
And whatsoever that he would,
their Names must called be.
And when the Lord did Adam place
in Paradice upright,
Oh then the Devil he did rage,
with all his wrath and spight.
And then he did purpose to have
him Captive at his Will,
And for to make of him his Slave,
did try his Hellish Skill.
At length into his wicked Claws
he got this famous Creature,
And made him for to break the Laws
of his own Precious maker.
And when that he had broke the Law
of his most blessed Guide,
Oh then he soon did run away,
and from the Lord did hide:
Unto the Fig-leaves he did go,
to shroud himself withall,
Though he did hear the Voice of God,
within the Garden call.
And when the mighty God did see,
that man was quite undone,
Immediately he did reveal
the Covenant with his Son.
My Son, he shall my Justice 'swa •• ,
which burneth doth so hot
Against poor, wretched, fallen man,
his Sin shall be forgot.
Most willingly did Christ comply,
in room of man to stand,
And so would fully satisfy
what Justice should demand.
Give Glory to this gracious God,
praise ye his Name on high,
Which did not leave poor, fallen Man,
in Hell and Misery.

div.head: II. A Dialogue between Moses, an Awakened Sinner, and JESUS CHRIST.

lg.l: OH that I could by Faith m ••• t up on high,
And on that splendid City fix mine Eye,
Where my Creator sits in Glory bright,
In presence of his Saints with great delight!
But while I wander in this Wilderness,
Surrounded here with Trouble, more or less,
And sinful Natu •• doth me so surprize,
I cannot •• ep saith up in Exercise.

Sometimes whe •
•
〈◊〉
• o the Throne of Grace,
The Lord doth seem from me to hide his Face,
Then I am dead, and dead returns again,
Which fills my Soul with Horror, Grief and Pain.
Likewise, my Heart it hath a Door, I find,
That lets in evil Thoughts into my mind;
Which makes my tim'rous Soul for to lament,
And fills me here with Wo and Discontent.
In-born Corruptions are in me most rife,
With me those Enemies they are at strife,
Moreover in this Wilderness doth go,
My furious Enemy, and potent Foe.
He runs, and goes and hurries, night and day,
To hunt, and take my Soul, to make't his prey,
And, Lyon-like, he after me doth follow,
And frights me with the Eccho of his Hollow.
O which way shall I go? where shall I run,
That so I may this fiery Dragon shun?
For if he doth but catch me in his Paws,
He then will me devour with his Jaws.
If that I could a Counsellor but find,
For to impart to him my troub ••• mind,
And if he in good Counsel have but Skill,
I will it take, let it be what it will.
Perhaps he may a way for me find out,
To ease me of my Trouble, Fear, and Doubt.
I know that Moses is both grave and wise,
I'll go to him, and hear what he'll advise:
But if I should my grief to him impart,
And he do no way ease me of my Smart,
I fear I shall go with a troubled Heart,
Until I do this mortal life depart.
Moses I come, with weeping Tears to thee,
Hoping some Comfort thou wilt give to me;
And that thou wilt unto me now declare,
Which way I shall escape this Hunter's Snare.
Come cease thy sad complaint, and mournful Tears,
And do not so possess thy Soul with fears,
I'll tell thee where thou may'st some comfort find,
If thou unto good Counsel art inclin'd.
Here is a Mountain in this Wilderness,
Where thou might'st go thy self for to refresh,
And there may hide from thy great Enemies,
That over thee they may not Tyranize.
'Tis call'd mount Sinai, where the Law was given,
If wholly kept, 'twill carry Souls to Heaven
Keep thou this Law, 'twill save thee from all evil,
'Twill keep thee from the World, the Flesh and Divel.
I pray tell me what is Contain'd therein,
That I with speed to keep it may begin,
For here I have but little time to stay,
Therefore I would make progress in my way;
For I unto this Law a Stranger am,
Therefore to me do thou relate the same;
I may it keep before my Life doth end,
And I will count thee for my dearest Friend.
For I am weary of this Wilderness,
And fain would blessed Canaan's Land possess,
This Wilderness is full of Pits and Bryers,
And often here my weary Soul it tires.

lg.head: I. Command.
lg.l: 18 There is but One True, living GOD you know,

l.hi: And that the Scripture plainly doth it show,
And thou must have no other gods but He,
Therefore beware of his Omnisciency.

lg.head: II. Command.
lg.l: 19 Ʋnto thy self no graven Image make,

l.hi: Lest that the Lord he do thee quite forsake;
For if this way thou dost him once provoke,
His Jealousie against thee hot will smoke.

lg.l: 20 If unto any thing he likened be,

l.hi: 'Twill be beneath his glorious Effency,
Therefore do thou beware of such a thing,
For it will thee into Perdition bring.

lg.head: III. Command.
lg.l: 21 God's sacred Name thou must not take in vain,

l.hi: Beware of that, lest guilty thou remain,
Nor speak of it without due Reverence,
But thou must strive God's Name for to advance.

lg.head: IV. Command.
lg.l: 22 The Sabbath-day thou must keep Holy too,

l.hi: And thou in it no manner of work must do;
No evil Thought must enter in thy Heart,
For then thou doss the Sabbath-day pervert:

lg.l: 23 Nor in thy House no Fire thou must make,

l.hi: For then thou dost the holy Sabbath break;
And in breaking one thou art guilty of the whole,
Which will bring Reprobation on thy Soul.

lg.head: V. Command.
lg.l: 24 Thy Parents thou must Honour and Obey,

l.hi: The Lord's Command expresly doth it say,
Lest he doth cut thee down from off the Earth,
And make thee like to an untimely Birth.

lg.head: VI. Command.
lg.l: 25 Thou must not Kill, that is a Crying Sin,

l.hi: And on thy Soul God's Vengeance it wil bring;
For Vengeance will pursue the bloody Man,
And find him out, do all that e'er he can.

lg.head: VII. Command.
lg.l: 26 Adultery also, thou must not commit,

l.hi: Lest God another day Judge thee for it,
Nor in thy Heart must not conceive a Lust,
For after Death thou then to Judgment must.

lg.head: VIII. Command.
lg.l: 27 Thou must not Steal, nor from thy Neighbor take,

l.hi: Lest that thou dost thy guilty Conscience make,
When on thy Death-bed then aloud to cry,
For Stealing to relieve thy Poverty.

lg.head: IX. Command.
lg.l: 28 Against thy Neighbour no false Witness bear,

l.hi: For then the Devil has thee in his Snare.
And if thou dost long time continue there,
Thy Soul will filled be with dismal fear.

lg.head: X. Command
lg.l: 29 None of thy Neighbors Goods thou must not covet

l.hi: Nor in thy Heart desire nothing of it;
Because 'tis counted for Idolatry,
And God doth see with his Omniscient Eye.

lg.l: 30 Thy Covetous Heart, and thy Desires too,

l.hi: And at the last will fill thy Soul with Woe,
'Cause thou hast made an Idol unto thee,
Which is forbid, as plainly thou may'st see.

lg.l: 31 Another thing I do declare to thee,
In Genesis the third, as thou may'st see:

l.hi: Thy first Parents did Eat Forbidden-fruit;
And that's the cause thy bonds are put in Suit.

lg.l: 32 When Adam broke God's possitive command;

l.hi: A perfect Man no longer could he stand;
For the Ten Precepts he did break withall,
Which makes thee guilty of the breach of all.

lg.l: 33 That possitive Command which Adam broke

l.hi: Has laid upon thee this most heavy Stroke:

lg.l: This is a Debt the Law will on thee lay,

l.hi: And thou this Debt must to a Farthing pay.

lg.l: 34 And if thou hast not wherewith to defend,
The Law will quickly thee to Prison send

l.hi: Ʋnless that thou a surety does get,
To rescue thee, and pay thy dang'rous Debt.

lg.l: Thou for this honour'd counsel I do thank;
But it hath brought me to the very brink
Of deep Dispair, 'cause it I cannot take,
Though I did such a solemn Promise make.
If I do break but one of God's commands,
Then of the rest thou say'st I guilty stands;
And I became a Debter to them all
When as I did in my first Parents fall.
I thought but for the Ten I was a Debter,
But now I see and understand it better:
Upon my Score I owe full for Eleven,
And this great debt will keep me out of Heaven.
'Twas Eve and Adam brought Sin-Original,
When they that great command did break and Fall
That makes me stand a naked criminal,
Nothing but Fig-leagues me to cloath withal.
It was for Fruit of the Forbidden-Tree,
And that great debt imputed is to me;
But I am Poor, this debt I cannot pay,
Therefore I must Sequest without delay.
Hold, do not think this way thy self to flatter,
Sequestring will not serve in this great matter,
Thou must a Surety get out of Hand,
To pay this debt and cancil thy black bond.
A bare Confession, Soul! will never do,
It will but bring upon thee greater woe;
For thou dost owe a very grievous debt,
Therefore thy self do not befool nor cheat.
Ah where's the Surety will undertake
For me a Bond-Slave, Free again to make;
The Fame of such a thing so Loud will Thunder,
That it will be the Universe's wonder.
Alas, and woe is me, I do lament:
Oh, whether shall I go my grief to vent:
I for my debt was troubled long before;
But now I am afflicted ten times more.
Canst thou no other way for me find out,
To ease me of my trouble, fear, and doubt:
If there's no other way my debts to pay,
I fear that I must in a Prison lye.
There is no other way that I can see
Whereby thou must from Prison be set free,
Unless thou hast a worthy Surety
To Stop the Law and Justice satisfy.
Dear Counsellor, I humbly of thee crave,
Tell me where I this Surety may have,
That I may hasten to him speedily,
And in a loathsome Prison may not lye.
There is a Prince of Fame and Royal blood
Which takes delight always in doing good:
He is the highest that was ever Born,
And yet thy Poverty he will not scorn,
If I unto this Royal Prince should go,
I have no Present on him to bestow:
The very truth unto thee I do show,
It is with me so very poor and low.
Had I a noble Present in my Hand,
I could the bolder then before him stand.
Mention this thing no more but take good heed,
For of a Present he has got no need;
And they that bring it he will not come near;
They do but cast themselves into a Snare.
The Heavens and the Earth are all his own,
And he beholden can be unto none:
He will except no Present thou canst bring,
Unless it be a broken Heart for Sin.
Then get a contrite Heart I thee advise;
For such a Present he will not despise:
He matters not whether they be high or low;
The Jew, the Greek, the Barbarian also.
He kindly doth receive it of all Men
And Women too, which brings it unto him;
The Rich, the Poor, the Halt, the Blind, and Lame,
That ever to him with this Present came.
The Learned and the Unlearned beside;
He never did this Present yet deride;
The Noble, and Ignoble, Bond, and Free;
The King, and Begger is alike to He.
He is a mighty Prince of high Renown,
And worthy is to wear the greatest Crown;
He is a glorious One, of noble Birth;
And thou a broken Potsherd of the Earth.
Go now with speed, and lay thy self down low,
And unto him thy sad condition show;
For he a Surety will be compleat,
To all that come and lye low at his Feet.
He's all divine, I nothing of it doubt;
But where shall I go for to find him out:
If I did know where he doth keep his Court,
I unto him am willing to resort.
He keeps his Court in new Jerusalem;
If thou art willing to resort to him,
Go often to the Foot-stool of his Grace,
And there, by Faith, thou may'st behold his Face
Upon his Mercy-seat thou may'st him see;
For there he always doth delight to be;
And both his hands are full of Pardons free;
Run now with speed, he holds one forth to thee.

div.head: The Heavy-laden Sinner making its address from the Law, to Jesus. Gal. 3.24. Wherefore the Law was our School-master to bring us unto Christ.

lg.l: My Lord and King, on me some pitty take,
And do this thing for thy great Mercy's sake:
Forgive the Punishment due unto me,
And save me from eternal Misery.
I do confess I am a Sinner vile,
And I do not deserve of thee one smile:
Therefore I humbly lye down at thy Feet,
And there to Perish, if thou think'st it meet.

l.hi: Whence cometh this most sad and grievous cry?

lg.l: From one which now Lord, at thy Feet doth lye.
A Heavy-laden Sinner, full of grief,
Which now is come to thee for some relief.
Poor wretched Soul, who sent thee unto me
That thou dost thus implore my Majesty.
Moses, a faithful Servant, Lord, of thine,
And first he sent me to the Law divine;
But when he did my sad condition know,
He said the Law would me no favour show.
What, would the Law no comfort yield to thee;
Nor give a clear discharge and set thee free?
No Lord, it is a holy righteous Law,
Which makes all such as I am stand in awe:
Therefore to go to it I do not dare,
It wounds and drowns and drives me to dispair
And I alas, can have no comfort there.
Come grieved Soul, which in dispair art droun'd,
Oh, turn again, that is a Sin profund:
Come unto me, and I will thee advise;
For I am nigh to hear poor Sinners cryes.
Look in God's word, and thou mayst clearly see
I did a ransome dearly pay for thee:
Thou art the purchase of my precious Blood,
As thou may'st find in God's most holy Word.
My Father's Justice I did satisfy,
When I upon the bloody Cross did die;
And all thy debt the Law doth now demand,
When on the Cross I paid it out of hand.
Therefore, by Faith, do thou cleave fast to me
For I am now, a Surety for thee;
And while thou art in this dark Wilderness,
I will be unto thee a strong defence.
And when thy Enemies do strive to foil thee,
I will be nigh, with Armour for to Shield the.
Ah, happy News, I have a Surety;
But woe alas, here lyes my Misery,
If I should wander out of the right way;
A guide I stand in need of every day.
God's Holy-Spirit, he will be thy guide;
Therefore do thou walk close up to his side:
He Pen'd the Scripture to be thy director,
And I my self will be thy great Protector.
The Holy-Spirit, and God's Holy Word
(For thy defence) is like a two-edg'd Sword,
Which will put thy great Enemies to flight,
If thou hast but the Skill to use it right.
God doth afford his Armour great and strong,
For unto Warr'ers it doth still belong;
Such Warr'ers that will fight against Hell's crew
And keep the Battle always in pursue.
Such Warr'ers as doth often Face about
To give their inborn Sin a total rout.
Come put on God's strong Armour all compleat
And then the Tyrant thou wilt quickly beat.
Thou must begirt about thy Loins with Truth
A Girdle glorious to be worn in Youth:
Thy Brest-plate must be of my Righteousness,
Or else my Kingdom thou canst not Possess.
Thy Feet be'ng shod with Gosp • l preparation:
Thou'lt seek for Peace and tidings of Salvation
Be sure to take the Shield of Faith also;
For through this howling Desert thou must go,
And if thou meet thy Enemy by and by,
His fiery Darts at thee he will let fly;
But thrô the Shield of Faith they cannot enter;
They will return again unto the center.
The Helmet of Salvation thou must hold;
And with the Spirit's Sword thou must be bold;
Then fight and skirmish often with thy Sin,
And never leave till thou the field dost win.
And do not vex me with thy cursed Sin,
Since I for thee a Surety have been:
Remember I from Prison thee reliev'd,
And do not thou my Holy-Spirit grieve.
See in presumptious Sins thou dost not dwell,
And think that all things now with thee is well,
Because for thee I did the Law revoke,
And kept thee from the heavy dreadful stroke
Of God's offended Justice which did rage
Against thy Sin, and would with thee ingage.
My Lord before thee here I trembling stand,
I willing am to be at thy command:
Oh Lord, if thou but Strength wilt give to me,
Under thy Fanner I will fight for thee.
Against Presumption I will sto • t • y fight,
And strive my inborn Sin to put to flight;
This I trust do by thy Almighty hand;
For I am weak, I can't the Battle stand.
Thou know'st, O Lord, I am but dust and clay,
Therefore set thou the Battle in array,
And weild thy Sword, and win the Field for me,
And all the Glory I will give to thee.
Poor Sinner now thou art come unto me,
I'll tell in part what I have done for thee;
I and my Father made both Heav'n and Earth;
We gave all Living, Substance, Life, and Breath.
But some of the created Angels fell,
And then my Father threw them down to Hell;
Then all Mankind fell in Rebellion too,
And made themselves Heirs of eternal Woe.
Then I stept in, Mankind for to Reprieve,
Even all such which in me shall believe;
The fallen Angels I did them pass by,
And left them in Eternal misery.
But after this it was my Pleasure then
That I would come and Live with sinful Men;
I came unto my own, my own refus'd me,
And more then that they greatly did abuse me.
When I was Born, and of a Virgin pure,
I did some hardship quickly then endure;
As soon as I was taken from the Womb,
Was in a Manger laid, for want of Room.
This was the manner of my noble Birth,
Although I was then Lord of all the Earth;
Then bloody Herod try'd his hellish Skill,
In order to fulfil his bloody Will.
He sent forth Tyrants poor young Babes to slay,
In hopes to shed my innocent blood that way;
But God their Tragedy did soon prevent,
Me and my Mother into Egypt sent.
When I was grown in stature of a Man,
I then did go up to Jerusalem
To Preach my holy Gospel to the Jews,
But they my holy Gospel did refuse.
I laboured among them Night and Day.
And all to turn their Faces Sion way:
I healed all the Sick, and all the Lame,
And pitty'd all that ever to me came,
The meanest of them I did not deride;
But yet for all they could me not abide:
I made the Dumb to speak, the Deaf to hear,
The Blind to see, as plainly did appear:
Yet still they did revile me at their Will,
And so took Counsel how they might me kill;
They hired Judas me for to betray,
In hast to send me from the Earth away;
And Thirty Silver Pieces they did give,
Because that I no longer here should live;
Then Judas he betray'd me with a Kiss;
No treachery was ever like to this!
But when the hour was come, as I had said,
And not till then, I could not be betray'd,
I bound was led unto the Judgment-hall,
And then on me those Rebels they did fall.
Then unto Pontius Pilate I was brought,
And there accused, but it was for nought;
Though I always was doing of them good,
Yet still they long'd and thirsted for my blood,
When Pontius Pilate sought to set me free,
Mine Enemies then they did all agree:
Of Barrabas they would not be deny'd;
But as for me, I must be Crucify'd.
Though I no evil ever did to them;
But yet they cry'd away, away with him,
It was their custom always at the Feast,
A Prisoner should be to them releast.
They did desire Barrabas for them;
But as for me they said, away with him;
Then very fast they bound me with their bands
And then they smote me with their cruel hands
They spit upon my Face, and did not spare;
And from my Cheeks they palled off the hair.
My Body also sore they buffetted;
And with a Reed they smote me on the head;
Above all Men, my Visage it was mar'd,
They did me crucify so cruel hard.
I was derided with their mocks and scorns;
And I was crowned with a Crown of Thorns;
Also they gave me Vinegar and Gall;
And made me wear a Purple Robe withal.
My Hands and Feet was nailed to a Tree;
A death which they appointed had for me:
My tender Side they pierced with a Spear;
And then came forth both blood and water clear.
God's dreadful Cup of Justice I did drink;
'Twas very bitter, yet I did not shrink;
I drank the dregs fill'd up unto the brim,
Because thou should'st in endless pleasure swim.
The Cup of Justice was so very hot,
It caused me to sweat a bloody Sweat;
Like drops of Blood falling down to the ground
On no Man yet the like was ever found:
And when that I had overcome my smart,
My Raiment then amongst them they did part;
The Soldiers they did likewise all agree,
That they would cast Lots on my Vestery.
My Body from the Cross was taken dead
And in a new Sepulchre buried,
Where never Man was ever laid before;
Also a Seal was set upon the Door.
But when I had lain in the Grave three days,
By my Almighty Power I did raise
The self same Body which hung on the Tree;
Here be the Wounds the Jews then gave to me:
I suffer'd all this grief and pain for thee,
And yet thou art now welcome unto me.
Oh boundless Love! oh Love beyond degree
My Lord and Saviour's Reconcil'd to me!
Ye blessed Angels, Heavens glorious Quire,
Here is a Love for you all to admire.
Here is a Love, a matchless Love indeed;
Ye Saints on Earth, be all astonished;
For ther • is now no other Love but this
Can bring your Souls to endless Happiness.

div.head: A Meditation composed into Verse, on the Song of Solomon, where Christ is setting forth the beauty of his Church, and the Church setting forth Christ's Excellency.

lg.l: O Who is She that looketh forth so soon,
Clear as the morning fairer than the moon?
It is my Spouse, my Sister and my Dove,
And it is She on whom I set my Love.
My Dove, my Undefiled is alone;
She is her Mother's choice, and only one;
For there is none that can with her compare,
And I will take of her a tender care.
My Love come unto me now I invite;
For I in thee do take a great delight;
Thou art most White, and like the Chrystal fair,
Thy Beauty I upon my heart do bear.
Thine Eyes compared is unto the dove,
And for to look on them I dearly love,
And 'specially when thou dost cast them up
To look on me in a well-grounded hope.
Thy Cheeks are very comely for to see,
L • ke rows of Jewels they appear to be:
Thou art most comely too in each degree
When thou by Faith dost look up unto me,
Thy Temple-locks are lovely to be seen:
Thy comely Speech doth render thee a Queen;
When thou approchest humbly unto me,
And by Repentance crave a pardon free.
Thy Lips are like a thred of Scarlet-silk;
Thy Neck like to a stately Tower built;
One Chain of thy white Neck has ravish't me;
For thou art fair, and hast no spot in thee.
Thy comely Eye doth overcome me so,
It makes my Majesty to stoop so low
As to place on thee my endeared Love,
And I again will never it remove.

div.head: The Church setting forth Christ's Excellency.

lg.l: My Well-beloved is the Prince of Peace,
And I do long to see his comely Face;
He's white and ruddy like the Diamond fair;
There is no beauty can with him compare.
His eyes are as the eyes of doves compleat;
His Cheeks are as a Bed of Spices sweet;
His Lips like Lillies dropping down sweet myrrh,
No fragrant Flower can with it compare.
His Countenance it is as Lebanon,
And excellent above the Sons of men:
Oh all ye Daughters of Jerusalem,
This is my Well beloved honour him.
This is my Well-beloved, and my Friend,
Ye Daughters see you do on him attend;
And he is cloathed in a glorious dress;
On him he has a Robe of Righteousness:
His Robe is white, and reacheth to the ground,
And in his Robe his glory doth abound:
See here's a Jasper, and a Saphire clear,
Most lovely it upon him doth appear.
A Chalcedony and an Emarald,
It is a pleasant fight for to behold:
See here's a Sardius and a Chrysolite;
Enough to dazle all beholders sight.
Here is a Sardonix, and now look there,
A Beril, and a Tophaz doth appear:
Look here's a Crysophrasus with the rest,
Also the Jacinct, and the Amethist;
Which makes me sick of love for my sweet Prince,
And pained till I am removed hence;
For love I find it is as strong as Death,
And Jealousie it burneth up my breath.
Oh set me as a Seal upon thy heart,
And never let my love from thee depart:
Ye Daughters of Jerusalem be kind,
And if you do my well beloved find,
I pray do you declare that it is I
Am sick of Love for him, and like to die.
He is the sweetest Rose of Sharon's field;
Oh come and taste the sweetness he doth yield!
He is the Lilly of the Valley fair,
Also he is the bright and morning Star.

div.head: A Meditation on the impotent Mans waiting at the Pool of Bethesda. John 5.

lg.l: THere was a Pool once at Jerusalem
Also five P • r ••• es there was standing by
Wherein the With'red, Blind, and Halt did lye;
For the diseased People thither came,
Because the Waters had so great a Fame;
But that which made the Waters for to heal,
It was an Angel sent for to reveal
The Power of the great Physician high,
When as the People at the Pool did lye;
For at a certain time an Angel did
Come down, and so the Water troubled
Then whosoever slept into the Pool,
Was cured and perfectly made whole:
A certain man with an Infirmity
Thirty eight years, did at Bethesda lye,
Waiting the moving of the Waters then,
And he long 〈◊〉 had there a waiting been:
Our blessed Sa • iour thither did draw nigh,
And on the poor Impotent cast his Eye.
But the impotent man did not espy
It was the great Physician standing by:
When Jesus saw him lye, and knew that he
Long time had been in great extremity;
He said to him wilt thou be now made whole,
Because he did his misery condole:
The poor Impotent answered him, Sir!
I have no Friend (when as the Waters stir)
Will lend a hand and help to put me in,
Though I long time have here a waiting been;
But while I coming am down to the Pool,
Another steppeth in, and is made whole.
Our blessed Lord said to the man, arise,
Take up thy Bed before beholders eyes;
The man he was immediately made whole;
None could the great Physician then controul.

div.head: The Author's Reflection.

lg.l: This is an Emblem of my Misery,
Here I a poor impotent one doth lye,
Waiting the moving of the Waters clear,
I mean the Spirit of my Saviour dear.
My Soul, which is the chiefest part of me,
Both withered and dry appea •• to be
The Faculties thereof are Halt and Blind,
Which daily I unto my grief do find.
Oh that the great Physician would draw nigh,
And on a poor Impotent cast an Eye!
Oh that he would my misery condole,
And speak the Word and I shall be made Whole.
Lord, there's no Pool on Earth can do me good,
But the pure Ocean of thy precious Blood.
There's nothing else can purifie and cleanse
My Wounded Soul from putrifying Sins.
Therefore, O Lord, thy precious blood apply
Ʋnto my Soul, that healing Remedy
Is a sweet Cordial which will me revive,
And keep my wither'd fainting Soul alive.
Lord now with speed this Cordial to me bring,
And fill me up a Cup unto the brim.

div.head: A Dialogue between Christ and a Young-man.

lg.l: I Walked have long time about to find
Some new-found pleasure to delight my mind;
But in my pleasure this doth me prevent,
I in my pleasure have no true content.
When I am merry with my Jolly Boys,
I then am checkt within, which damps my Joys;
Likewise I take delight in sports and plays,
In it I spend away my Nights and Days;
But afterwards my heart's fill'd with Reflection,
Which almost has brought me into subjection.
Oh that I could the reason of it know,
What is the cause it should be with me so,
I would some cure soon for it then look out,
Although I ranged all the World about.
It is thy Conscience which doth trouble thee,

l.hi: And makes thee so dissatisfy'd to be;
Because in merriment thou dost offend
Thy Sov'reign Lord, on whom thou should'st depend.

lg.l: Conscience if it be so, I'll make thee Sleep,
And then my mind I shall in quiet keep;
For if thou dost thus trouble me alway,
Then I shall never see a happy day.
If I do Sleep, I shall awake again,
And then I will put thee to greater pain;
I ll pinch and cut and lash thee bitterly,
Ʋntil I maketh thee aloud to cry.
Conscience thou threat'nest me so very sore,
I hope I never shall offend thee more;
And seeing thou profess to be my Friend,
I'll take my leave, and so we both will end.
This will not do with me, I am afraid,
I must look out yet for some other aid.
Oh that my ways were but so now directed,
That for the future I might be protected;
And that I may some other object find,
To give content to my unsettled mind.

l.hi: Young-man if of thy ways thou hast a fight,
And it doth seem to thee not to be right,
God's word doth show thee what thou ought to do,
To cleanse thy ways by taking heed thereto.
And if thou dost desire more to know,
I ready am and willing thee to show;
I'll show thee objects shall give thee content,
And give thee pleasure when thy life is spent.
Nay, more then so I'll give a promise higher,
I'll give thee all thy heart can e'er desire,
If thou with speed wilt now close in with me.

lg.l: Everlasting Treasure I will give to thee.
'Tis endless pleasure which my heart doth crave
And lasting pleasure, which I fain would have;
If thou this promise wilt make good to me,
I am resolv'd to close in now with thee.
I willing am to part with all my Sin,
Which as I hitherto have lived in,
My sports and pleasures and my Jolly Boys,
I count them all even but empty Toys.
If thou wilt close with me, then take good heed
Thou must into my Vineyard go with speed,
And Labour there till I do for the send,
Thy Labour then I'll put unto an end.
I in the Garden laboured for thee,
Then in my Vineyard labour thou for me:
I trod the Winepress, I my self alone,

l.hi: Which made me in my Spirit so to moan.
And of the People, there was none with me,
To work out thy Redemption-work for thee;

lg.l: It was not for my self I took this care,
I had no need of any thing to fear.
No, 'twas to keep thee from the Serpent's sting,
I had been happy had'st thou never been.
Dear Lord, I smitten am to hear thee speak,
My heart within me now is like to break
To think that thou hast done so much for me,
And I a wretch have nothing done for thee.
Into thy Vineyard now I'll go away,
And I will labour there both Night and Day;
But Vineyard work is hard, and I am Weak,
Lord strengthen me this work to undertake.
Appoint the work Lord, thou wilt have me do,
For I am yet Stranger thereunto.
Some of thy Work must be to plant and sow,
And other some must be to reap and mow;
All superfluous Branches thou must lop,
Or else I shall not have a thriving crop.

l.hi: Do thou take care my tender plants to nourish

lg.l: For I love dear to see them thrive and flourish

l.hi: Thou also must plant in the choicest Soil,
Then of thy Fruit there's none shall thee beguile
Likewise thou must root out the stinking weed
That they may not over top my pure Seeds;
But first thou must with thy own self begin,
And root out all thy own in dwelling Sin.

lg.l: If thou art willing they should in thee lurk
Thou art not fit for this my Vineyard-work;
In Snow or Hail my work must still go on;
Thou must not take a spell, and then be gone.
In wet and heat and thunder thou must bide,
And not to run away whate'er betide;
When lofty winds does blow and rain descend,
My work thou must keep to until the end.
If I must labour in the Snow and Hail,

l.hi: The pinching cold will over me prevail;

lg.l: If in the wet and heat, then I shall faint;

l.hi: Likewise the thunder sorely will me daunt.

lg.l: When rain descend, and stormy winds do blow
Alas, how shall I to my labour go;
This task it is too hard for me, I fear.

l.hi: My earthen Vessel never will it bear.

lg.l: Therefore do thou Lord undertake for me,
That I thy Vineyard-work may do for thee;
For thou dost know that I am but a worm,
I crave the strength of thy Almighty hand,
That I before thee in this work may stand.
Thou art a Worm I know, and also weak,
And I the work myself must undertake;
When thou dost work for me in Snow or Hail,
I will cover the with my secure vail:
Which vail shall cover me so very warm,
The pinching cold shall never do thee harm;
I'll shelter thee too from the parching heat,
So that upon thy head it shall not beat.
I'll cause a gourd to spring up like a Rose,
Where thou shalt lye and take a sweet repose;
But if I please to take this gourd from thee
(Like unto Jonah) do not angry be.
The lofty winds I holdeth in my First,
And I can make them blow which way I list;
Thee I will into my pavilion bring,
And over thee will spread my saving wing.
When flouds descend I will for thee provide,
And in the hollow of my hand thee hide,
Where evermore in safety thou shalt be,
If thou art willing still to work for me;
For I will do my part as thou shalt see,
Because my work easy be to thee:
My Vineyard I will hedge in round about,
To keep the wild Boar of the Forrest out,
That so he may not break my tender Vine,
Which does begin about me for to twine;
For he about the hedge doth lye and lurk,
To enter in and spoil my Vineyard-work.
He and all other such like rav'nous Beast,
Ʋpon my choicest Grapes delights to Feast;
But he and they with all their strength and malice,
My Vineyard shall not hurt nor yet demolish.
The Valleys I will fill with mod'rate showers,
For to refresh my tender plants and Flowers,
On them I will my warming dews distill,
And cause them to send forth their fragrant smell.
Ʋpon my Flowers gentle Gales shall blow,
To take off all the dust, that they may show
Most pleasant and delightful to mine Eye,
When I about my Vineyard do pass by.
I often walk my Vineyard, for to see
If any of my Servants idle be,
And if my Labourers do work and toil,
I often give to them a pleasant smile:
But if my Servants loitering are found,
Then I on them doth give an angry frown;
It's for their good that I do serve them so,
That they no more a loitering may go.
Remember thou much of thy time hast spent,
Thy time now to redeem be diligent
Labour therefore with all thy force and might,
And I will give to thee what is thy right,
A Penny thou shalt have as well as they
Which bore the heat and burden of the day.

div.head: A Meditation composed into Verse, on the 25th. Chapter of Matthew.

lg.l: TEN Virgins took their Lamps and went
their Bridegroom for to meet;
But five of them their Oyl had spent;
their Lamps they could not fit;
For five of them were wise ye know,
the other foolish were,
Yet they for company would go,
their pains they would not spare:
And they like fools did nothing doubt,
but took their Lamps with them,
And did not for no Oyl look out,
until the Bridegroom came:
But while the Bridegrom tarried
a little by the way,
All those Ten Virgins slumbered,
and so they sleeping lay,
Until a midnight-cry there was,
to call them from their sleep:
Behold! the Bridegroom coming is,
go forth ye him to meet.
Then all those Virgins did arise
their Lamps to fit and trim,
And the five Virgins that were wise
their Lamps fill'd to the brim.
The foolish Virgins did not so;
no Oyl they had in store,
Therefore their Lamps they out did go,
never was lighted more.
The Fools then to the Wise did say,
give us now of your Oyl;
For we must hasten soon away,
now we have heard our call.
The Wise then said unto them no,
we dare not be so bold;
Rather unto the place now go
where it is to be sold;
For if we give our Oyl to you,
our Vessels be so small;
Then we shall want it to renew,
and trim our Lamps withal.
The foolish Virgins they had been
lingring so long before,
Until the Bridegroom entred in
and shut them out of Door.
But them that ready was before
unto the Marriage went,
Their Bridegroom ever to adore,
unto their hearts content.
The other Virgins with vain hope,
said, Lord! open to us,
And if thou wilt the Door but ope,
then we will be thy Guess.
These Virgins unto the Door came,
as though they Oyl had got:
But then the Lord did say to them,
verily I know you not.
But when the Son of Man shall come
with all his glorious train,
To sit upon his Father's Throne,
for ever to remain.
All Nations gathered shall be,
before him they shall stand,
And they shall Separated be,
by his Almighty hand.
And as a Shepherd doth divide
clear from the Goats the Sheep;
Christ for his Sheep will then provide;
he will them safely keep.
His Sheep shall sit at his Right-hand,
none shall them hunt away;
The Goats shall stand at his Left-hand,
but little time to stay:
And then the King will say to all
that sits at his Right-hand,
Enter the Kingdom great and small;
possess my holy Land.
When I was Hungry you did Feed
my pinched Body poor,
And did administer to my need
when I stood at your Door.
When I was Sick, and very Weak,
a Stranger poor and thin,
Then on me you did pity take,
and you did let me in.
When Naked was you did me Cloath:
when Thirsty gave me Drink;
When others did my Person loath,
and scarce on me did think:
And when I did in Prison lye,
oppressed there with grief,
Ye came to see my misery,
and gave me some relief.

div.head: And then shall the Righteous say.

lg.l: Lord when saw we thy Body so
oppressed thus with grief,
And when did we unto thee go,
and gave to thee relief.

div.head: Then shall the King answer.

l.hi: Do not inquire how or when,
now you this thing shall see,
If done unto my Bretheren,
you'ave done it unto me.
Enter into my Kingdom now,
and you shall plainly see,
All Nations do before me bow,
and eke rejoyce in me;
For it prepared was for you,
before the World begun,
And with my Blood purchas'd anew,
which from my Side did run.
The King will say unto them all,
which are at his left hand,

lg.l: Depart, ye Cursed great and small,
no longer here shall stand.
Into Perdition you shall go,
which is prepar'd for you,
To weep and wail in endless wo,
depart ye cursed Crew.
When I was Hungry, you did slight
my pinched Body poor,
And with your Tongues you did me smite,
and drove me from your Door.
When I was Sick and very weak,
a Stranger poor and thin,
Then you of me a Scoff did make,
and would not take me in.
When I did bare and naked go,
you did not on me think,
When I was faint with Thirst also,
you gave to me no Drink.
And when I did in Prison lye
oppressed there with Grief,
The Prison you would not come nigh,
to give to me relief.

div.head: Then shall the Wicked say

lg.l: Lord when did we thy Body see,
oppressed thus with Grief,
And did not minister unto thee,
to give to thee Relief?

div.head: CHRIST's Answer.

lg.l: To you this Parable shall be shown,
and now you shall it see,
You done it not to these my own,
you done it not to me.
And these shall go to endless wo,
for ever to remain,
The Righteous into Bliss also,
like Princes for to reign.
YE Virgins now no longer sit
drowsing as you have been,
For when the Bridegroom's Door is shut
there is no entring in.
Ye Sleepy Virgins of this Land,
trim up your Lamps with speed,
The Midnight Cry is near at hand
therefore beware, take heed,
And do no longer Sleeping lay
but on your Watch be found,
Then in that blessed marriage day
your Joys they will abound.

div.head: The Author's Request.

lg.l: LORD give me Oyl of thy Free Grace
my Vessel for to fill,
And help me to run out my Race,
in doing of thy will.
Help me to cleanse my Lamp about
from all the stinking Snuffs,
So that it may not Wiffer out
with any windy Puffs.
But that my Lamp it may burn clear,
to light me on the way,
That I may meet my Bridegroom Dear,
him to Adore for Aye.
Lord give me Talents, Two or Five,
which seemeth good to thee,
Them to Improve, then I will strive,
Lord give them unto me.
But if it be thy Pleasure, Lord,
to give to me but One,
And I should in the Earth it hoard,
then I shall be Undone.
Therefore my God, for Jesus sake,
give me a bigger Portion,
And grant I may it double make,
unto my great Promotion.
Oh grant I may not be like him,
which in his Heart shall say,
My Lord delayeth for to come,
he will yet longer stay.
But that I may both Watch and Pray,
and waiting be also,
That when my Lord shall come, I may
be ready for to go.

div.head: A Meditation on Luke the 19th.

lg.l: OUR blessed Lord and King is gone
a Kingdom to receive,
And for to purchase them a Crown
that doth on him believe:
But when he will return again,
no mortal Man can show;
And to inquire 'tis in vain,
the Angels do not know.
The King called his Servants then,
which was in number Ten;
The meaning of the Parable,
it is all sorts of Men.
He gave a Pound to ev'ry one,
as you may plainly see,
In order for to trade upon,
that none may idle be:
And when the King does come again
those Servants he will call,
To see where it be spent in vain,
what they should trade withal.
The first unto the King shall say,
thy Pound hath gained Ten;
I willing was to trade each day,
till thou didst come agen.
The second also he shall say,
thy Pound hath gained Five;
I willing was to trade alway,
that I with it may thrive.
You good and faithful Servants are,
the King will then reply;
You of my Treasure takes a care,
and did not idle lye.
Enter therefore, into my rest,
my glorious Throne to see,
And you shall evermore be blest,
to all Eternity.
Another came and he did say,
Lord, here's thy Pound again,
I did up in a Napkin lay,
lo! here it doth remain.
I know thou art an austere Man;
of thee I was afraid:
Therefore I kept it in my hand,
and would not with it trade.
Thou gatherest, but wilt not strew,
and reap, but wilt not sow;
And thou dost keep all in thy view,
nothing thou wilt let go.

div.head: Then shall the King say;

lg.l: If thou hast known me such an one,
for to exact on thee,
Thou shouldst my Money then have thrown
into the Ʋsury.
Thou wicked art, and sloathful too;
thy Mouth hath Judged thee;
Thou shalt to outward darkness go;
appointed 'tis by me.

l.hi: When this is done, the King will rise,
and to his Angels say;

lg.l: Bring forth all those mine Enemies,
before me now and slay.
The Drunkards, and False Swearers all
before me come and slay;
They would not hearken to my call,
nor yet my Voice obey.
Both Lyers, Whore-mongers, and Proud,
which live in high renown;
They for my Vengeance cry aloud,
on them to pour it down.
Come bring the Thief, and Covetous,
with all the wicked Race,
And all that hate my holy Laws,
slay them before my Face.
Come bring forth the Lascivious crew,
the Hypocrite also;
For they together now must rew,
and in the Lake must go.
The Glutten, and the Revellours,
and Sabbath-breakers too,
They all must share like Levellours;
their Mirth will end in woe.
Come forth those wicked Sinners all,
living and dying so;
For • ou under my Wrath shall fall,
and into Hell must go.

div.head: The Author's Request.

lg.l: Lord, lend me thy Almighty hand,
and I will trade for thee,
And grant I in the Lot may stand
with them that Saved be.

div.head: A Meditation on the 9th. 10th. and 11th. Chapters of Exodus.

lg.l: THE Childeren of Israel
must unto Egypt go,
And there as Strangers they must dwell;
the Lord had spoken so:
And for full four hundered Year,
as you may plainly see;
In Bondage they afflicted were,
under Pharoah's cruelty:
For Pharoah, and his Servants they,
on them such Burdens laid,
Which made them to cry out and say
we greatly are dismay'd.
Their Task-masters they were so cruel,
and did them so afflict;
They would allow them no more Fuel
wherewith to burn their Brick:
Yet you shall the full Tale return
from each particular Man;
But you shall have no Straw to burn;
get Straw where e'er you can:
And when their Masters threatned so,
It smote their Hearts with trouble,
Then they unto the Fields did go,
and plucked up the Stubble.
In order to fulfil their Tale,
full hard to work they went,
In hopes that they should then prevail
their Masters to content.
But they could not their work compleat,
as they had done before,
Then Pharoah's Servants did them beat,
'cause they had done no more.
They were with Burdens bowed down,
and they had no relief;
And Pharoah that did wear the Crown,
he added to their grief:
Then to the Lord they made their moan,
and unto him did cry;
So that the Lord did hear them groan
under their misery;
And for his own great mercy's sake,
his People he will save;
And for the Cov'nant he did make,
and unto Abra'am gave.
Moses and Aaron, they must show
this message to the King,
Now you must let all Israel go,
these tidings they did bring.
The Lord sent us thee to advise,
to let this People rest;
For they to him must Sacrifice,
in the great Wilderness.
The King then in a rage did say,
it never shall be so;
Who is the Lord, I should Obey,
in letting Israel go?
The Lord, Jehovah is his Name,
and soon thou shalt him know,
By Signs and Wonders of great Fame,
to morrow he will show.
The Lord then smote them all with Blood,
throughout their Land so wide;
They had no Water that was good,
so that for Thirst they cry'd.
He sent amongst them Frogs and Flys,
and Murrain on their Beast,
And all to ope their darkned Eyes,
that they from Sin might cease.
God sent them Lice, with Hail, and Fire,
and Pestilence also;
But Pharoah yet had no desire
to let poor Israel go.
The Locusts they did vex them sore,
yet all was but in vain;
For Pharoah's heart was hardned more,
and so he did remain.
Then God did send them one Plague more,
with great contempt and scorn,
Which made th' Egyptians for to roar;
he slew all their First born:
Then Pharoah rose up in the Night,
and thrust them from his Land;
For he did see the Lord did fight
with his Almighty hand.
The wise Magicians of the Land,
they all were sore affrighted;
Before the Lord they could not stand;
for they were all benighted.
But when the King did understand,
that Israel was gone,
And that no more into his Land
they never would return:
Then Pharoah after Israel went,
with all his mighty host;
For in his heart was no content,
he after them did Post;
And found them Campt by the Red-Sea,
then thought they were his own;
But Pharoah and his mighty host,
they soon was over-thrown.
Then to the Lord did Israel cry,
for they were sore afraid,
When they beheld their Enemy
coming with mighty aid:
And then they did with Moses chide,
and vexed him full sore;
Would God we had in Egypt dy'd,
and had been seen no more.
Because their were not Graves enough
in Egypt for to lye;
Therefore you now have brought us forth
i'th' Wilderness to die.
Then God did make the Sea to stand
on each side on a heap;
And God led Israel by the hand,
through that great mighty deep.
Then after them Pharoah did Post,
even at their very Heels;
Then God to trouble Pharoah's host
took off their Chariot Wheels;
So that their Chariots could not run,
nor after Israel go,
Until the Waters did return,
and them did over-throw.
Six hundred thousand great and small,
with flocks and herds also;
Nothing of Israel's did fail,
but through the Sea did go;
Because the Sea it was a Wall
for them on every side;
Also the Lord the chief of all
was unto them a guide.
It was not so with Pharaoh's host,
for God on them did frown;
Therefore they all in Sea was lost,
and all their Army drown'd:
And on the Morrow they lay dead,
in heaps upon the Shore;
Their Bodies lay unburied,
and they return'd no more.
To show the Power of the Lord,
in doing of this thing,
And that in all the World abroad,
the Fame thereof may ring.
But Israel out of that distress,
they tempted then the Lord,
And griev'd him in the Wilderness;
thus they did him reward.
His holy Laws, and Statutes pure,
then they did not regard,
And they could scarcely them indure,
their hearts were grown so hard.
They murmured along the way;
to Moses they reply'd,
Oh that we had not seen this day,
but had in Egypt dy'd;
For when we were in Egypt fed,
and by the Flesh-pot were;
Then we had all our fill of Bread,
of Onions had no spare:
But now we and our little ones,
our flocks and herds also,
For Thirst and Hunger often grones,
as we along doth go;
For this light Bread our Souls do loath,
our Stomachs it doth cloy;
This Manna that comes from above,
and feeds us every day.
When Israel did murmur thus,
the Lord strait-way did hear;
Therefore in the great Wilderness
he led them forty year.
Because they had provok'd him so,
the Lord did then prophess
They should not into Canaan go,
that good Land to possess:
But all your little ones shall go,
your flocks and herds beside,
Caleb, and Joshua also,
the Land for to divide.
When into Canaan they were got,
and in that Land did dwell,
Then they in Wickedness were hot,
they soon to Whoredom fell:
Then Jesuran waxt fat and thick,
and at the Lord did kick;
They had forgot when 'twas their Lot,
in Egypt to make brick.

div.head: A Meditation on Solomon's Temple.

lg.l: THere was a Temple in Jerusalem
Wherein the Lord Jehovah set his Name,
King Solomon the Temple he did build,
A finer Temple never was beheld.
It was a City of so great a Fame;
To Trafick thither many Nations came;
The Tribes of Israel was dwelling there,
Which was the Jews as plainly doth appear.
God with his gracious Presence blest them so,
Which made them into multitudes to grow;
Riches and Honour he to them did give,
And made them in that pleasant Land to Live.
Also his counsel he did give to them,
That they should Love, Obey, and Honour him,
And more than this, likewise he did provide;
He sent his Priests and Prophets them to guide,
And when they did of all that good pertake,
They quickly did their gracious God forsake:
His Priests and Prophets they could not abide;
Them they did mock and likewise sore deride.
And soon was turned out of the right way,
The Lord they would not honour nor obey,
The Lord Jehovah they did then contemn;
They would not yield he should reign over them:
But made them Idol-gods, and them did serve,
And from the true and living God did swerve:
The Lord their City then did over-throw,
Into Captivity he made them go:
And for their Infidelity and Pride,
Full Seventy Years he made them there abide.
When they were bound, and in Captivity,
Afflicted there with grief and misery;
They thought upon the goodness of their Lord,
Which formerly he did to them afford:
But then said they, his goodness we did slight;
Therefore we now are cast out of his sight.
Our dance is turned into great vexation,
Also our Joy into a Lamentation;
Likewise the Crown is fallen from our head;
And Wo to us, that ever we Sinned:
For this our hearts are faint, our eyes are dim,
Because we have so high provoked him
Which should have sway'd the Scepter over us,
Then we should not have been afflicted thus.
Lord, show to us thy mercy speedily;
Be not for ever with us angery:
Draw not thine anger out against us, Lord!
But unto us some pitty now afford.
Return, O Lord, and make thy City strong,
For unto thee the City doth belong;
It is thy own, and it was proved so,
When we into Captivity did go.
The Lord did hearken then unto their cry,
And brought them out from their Captivity;
He from their Enemies did them remove
Because he is a God of pure Love.
He brought them back unto their Scituation,
And them he visited with his Salvation.
Oh that the People they would praise the Lord,
For all his wondrous works he doth afford;
And for his goodness he extends to them,
In shewing mercy to the Sons of men;
The Longing Soul he filled hath with good,
The Hungry Soul refresheth with his food.
All of his People which did suffer wrong,
And were in Iron Fetters bound full strong;
When they did seriously upon him call,
He heard their cry, and brought them out of thrall.
Oh that the People they would praise the Lord,
For all his wondrous works he doth afford;
And for his goodness he extends to them,
In giving Pardon to the Sons of men.

div.head: A Meditation on Christ's Ancient Vine-yard.

lg.l: THE Lord of Glory had a Vine-yard fair,
Whereof he took a very tender care,
And he did hedge it in all round about,
Also the Stones he gathered them out.
He Planted it with the most choicest Vine,
Because it should yield him the sweetest Wine;
I'th' midst of it he built a Tower high,
For to be seen by all that passed by.
A Wine-press he did make therein also,
That the delicious Wine might overflow;
And when the Lord at this expense had been,
He Let it out unto some Husband-men:
And when the time of Fruit was almost come,
Then of the Fruit the Lord desired some;
He sent his Servants forthwith out of hand,
Unto his Husband-men for to demand
Some of the Fruit which did belong to him
But the vile Husband-men abused them;
Some of his Servants they did sorely beat,
The other they did evilly intreat,
These wicked Husband-men they killed one,
The other they most cruelly did Stone;
So then the Lord he sent forth Servants more
Than he had sent out at the time before:
But they did beat and kill them too likewise,
And did the Servants of their Lord despise:
But last of all he sent his Son to them,
Saying, they now will surely rev'rance him,
Whom when they saw amongst themselves did say,
This is the Heir let's make him clear away,
And let us sieze on his Inheritance;
For we thereby our selves shall high advance.
Out of their Vine-yard then they did him cast,
And their design they had on him at last;
They caught and bound, and then they did him kill,
And on him they fulfill'd their bloody Will.
The great Lord of the Vine-yard then was wrath
When they had slew his Son of Noble worth;
Their wicked doings did him so provoke,
It made his Anger hot against them smoke:
And then his Vine yard-wall he down did break
Which wall before for safety he did make,
And left it for the rav'nous Beasts of Prey,
Which wall is not made up unto this day.
The Vine-yard's eaten up the walls trod down,
Which was a Vine-yard once of high Renown;
And it is desolate unto this day,
Because the Lord did take the hedge away.
And then the Lord did scourge the Husbandmen
In order for to purge away their Sin;
Their Cities he most desolate did make,
And eke their Houses utterly forsake.
With Famine he did vex them very sore;
They never such a Famine felt before;
Their little ones they swooned in the Street,
Because they had no Bread for them to Eat.
Their Skin which was so ruddy fair and fat,
Like to an Oven it was turned black;
The Virgins hung their Heads down to the ground,
Because the Famine did so sore abound.
The sucking Infant at the Mother's breast,
Their Tongues cleav'd to their Mouths for very thirst;
While they for sustenance did seek about,
Their Souls did in their Bosoms pour out.
The delicate Women did her Children Eat
For want of Food the Famine was so great.
Young men and Virgins in the Streets did swoon'd,
Like to the Slain they lay upon the gro • nd.
The Lord did fill their Cities so with anguish,
Which made the rampart of the wall to languish,
Because upon the Lord's Inheritance
They siezed had, themselves for to advance.
The Elders mourning sat upon the ground,
Their Loyns with Sackcloth they had girded round
The pittiful Women sod their Children dear,
And did them Eat as plainly doth appear.
They were more cruel than the Osterige,
When they were cut with hunger in the siege;
The Lord to them no pitty did afford;
He slew the Priests and Prophets with the Sword.
Into Captivity then they did go,
And there the Lord did make them for to know
Their Wickedness which they to him had done,
In slaying of his dear and only Son.
Their famous City burned was with Fire,
According as their Sin did then require:
But yet the Lord has promised to call
Them back again, and bring them out of thrall;
Because the Lord a Covenant did make,
The Seed of Abra'am he will not forsake;
Then they shall it confess, and not deny
'Twas they his only Son did Crucify.

div.head: A Dialogue between Christ the Physician of Value, and a Soul sensible of the worth of his Cure.

lg.l: HO! every one that thirsteth come to me,
And Living-waters I will give you free;
Here's Milk and Wine, also it is my Will
That you shall drink thereof and take your fill.
Lord here am I a dry and thirsty one,
For draught my Flesh it cleaveth to the Bone;
My Heart is chapt, my Mouth is dried up,
Lord of thy Wine and Milk give me one sup
For to refresh my parched Heart so dry,
Now I am in this great Extremity:
Thou bid'st me come, but when I strive to go,
I am so weak I stagger to and fro.
I feeble am by reason of the Sting
Of strong Corruption and in dwelling Sin;
It has so wounded me in every part,
Also it has infected my whole Heart.
It has so filled me with grief and wo,
I know not what to say, nor what to do:
I am all over Leperous with Sin,
And I a long time lived have therein.
This Leprosie has over-run me so;
I am so faint I know not how to go;
And here upon my Couch of Earth I lye
A loathsome Spectacle in my own Eye.
My putrified Wounds corrupt and stink,
And yet from Death I ready am to shrink;
Because I know not whither I shall go,
Either to Bliss, or to eternal Wo.
I weary am to live, and loath to die,
Because this Body in the Earth must lye
A little while, and raised be again,
If not to Joy, to everlasting Pain.
The thoughts of this when I it think upon,
It makes me send up many a sigh and groan
Unto my ever blessed great Physician,
To pitty me in this my sad condition.
I even I can cure all thy pain;
For I can kill, and make alive again:
I bringeth down unto the Grave, and then
Again I say, return ye Sons of Men.
I have Rich Balsom which can cure thy smart,
And Pills to purge thy putrified Heart.
I have Rich Oyl to mollifie thy Bones
When thou dost send up to me sighs and grones.
I living water have to quench thy thirst,
If thou wilt live, this water drink thou must;
This water to thee I will freely give,
That thy poor thirsty Soul may drink and live.
What thô thy Flesh do wast away with pain,
I power have to raise it up again;
No weakness then shall compass thee about,
When I again shall make thee new throughout.
I am the great Physician, which can do
All cures unto thy Soul and Body too.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Give me these cures before, I faint and die.

lg.l: These cures they are partly of my treasure,
And I will give them to thee at my pleasure.
First I will give to thee a Cordial pure,
Which of it self will make a perfect cure;
Drink up this Golden-cordial, rich and good;
'Tis a compound made of my precious Blood.
This Cordial it will make thee for to sweat,
And out of every Vein Corruption set;
Thy hand of Faith unto me hold it up,
For I will give it strength to take this Cup.
Come take a draught, and nothing of it doubt,
Drink heartily the Cordial will hold out:
But in thy drinking take a special care,
Waste not a drop, it cost me very dear;
And yet I freely give it unto thee,
So that thy Soul may live again to me:
What, though thou art corrupt in every part,
Here is glad Tidings which will cheer thy heart.
I am a Fountain open set, for all
Which in me trust, and on my name do call:
And in the Fountain of my Blood, thy Soul
I'll wash and bathe, until made perfect whole:
But when thou art relieved from thy grief,
And hast by me obtained such relief;
See that thou willing art, and ready then
To strengthen thy poor feeble Bretheren.
Yet one more heavy burden I do bear,
Which to my great Physician I'll declare;
An Enemy I meet with every day,
And dreadful strokes upon me he does lay.
He with his darts of evil thoughts doth wound
My Soul, which makes my misery abound;
His grand design, and purpose every way
Is, how he may my Soul and Body slay;
Therefore my Soul-Physician try thy skill,
That on me he may never have his Will.
Come, do not fear, I'll take this cause away,
By purging Potions I'll give thee each day;
For when I do but once take thee in hand,
Thine Enemy before me cannot stand;
And when my Skill I do begin to try,
This Enemy will quickly from thee fly.
But I have nothing for to satisfy
My Lord, for all his precious Remedy;
For since those miseries on me did fall,
In seeking of a cure, I have spent all.
Yes, thou hast got a never dying Soul,
Whose misery I cannot but condole;
Resign thy Soul to me I thee advise,
I'll take that as a living Sacrifice;
And give thy self to me and my Protection,
And that shall be to me full Satisfaction.
Thy offer, Lord, I will take at thy hand,
My Soul and Body is at thy command;
And seeing thou desirest no more gain,
I'll give it freely, take it for thy Pain.
If I had Souls a thousand millions more,
With all the Treasure of this floating Shore,
They were too little for to give to thee,
For all thy loving kindness unto me:
But I, alas, can never gratify
My blest Physician; therefore, till I dye,
I will be speaking of his glorious Name,
And spread abroad a little of his Fame.
Ye Sin sick Souls which are in misery,
See that you hast to this Physician high,
And he will quickly ease you of your smarts,
And give a Cordial to revive your hearts.
He heals the Dumb, the Blind, the Palsy Folk,
He makes the Deaf to hear, the Lame to walk;
He heals the Fever, and the Withered,
He raiseth up to Life those which are Dead,
He heals the Lepers be they ne'er so bad,
Also he heals the Lunatick, and Mad:
To them that comes unto him most in pain;
He handeth forth his Medicines amain.
The poorest Creature that is on the Earth,
Shall have of him as good a Penny worth
As any King that ever reigned here,
Although his Remedies they cost so dear.
And all he does require at our hands,
Is for to close in with his Gospel-bands;
Which is to Love, Serve, Honour, and Obey,
And magnifie him in your Souls alway.

div.head: The Author's Request to God that the Graces of his holy Spirit may be in a lively Exercise in her Soul.

lg.l: THE Graces of thy Spirit, Lord,
they are of mighty aid,
Them to thy poor weak Worm afford,
whereon I may be stay'd.
The Evidence of Faith I crave;
with true Repentance too;
I true Obedience fain would have;
with Charity also.
The Evidence of Patience, Lord,
and true Humility;
To me these Graces all afford,
and do not them deny.
Mortification I desire,
and Sanctification;
Justification to admire,
and him that hath it done:
And let not Self-denyal fail;
nor Hope, I humbly pray;
But let these Graces all prevail,
and live in me alway.
These Talents free, Lord give to me,
I earnestly beseech,
That with them I may trading be;
for they will me enrich.
And guide me with thy mighty hand,
that I may trade for thee;
And grant I in the Lot may stand
with them that Saved be.

div.head: A Meditation on the Day of Judgment.
div.l: WHen as the final Judgment-day is come,
Then Sinners look out for your fatal doom;
And when the Lord descendeth with a shout,
Ye Saints, do you triumphantly look out
To meet your gracious Lord, and glorious King,
That you to him may Hallelujahs Sing;
Also lift up your heads, and do not fear;
For your Redemption is a drawing near:
The Trumpet then shall sound, the Dead shall rise,
The Saints with Joys, the Sinners with sad cryes,
Weeping and wailing, loudly crying thus;
Ye Rocks and Mountains fall and cover us:
Those things they will be dreadful for to see;
Also the glorious Sun shall darkned be.
The Powers of the Heavens they shall shake,
And all the Earth most grievously shall quake.
The Heavens shall be rolled as a scroul:
Likewise, the Stars unto the Earth shall fall;
And then the World with Fire shall be burned,
And all things therein will be overturned.
And when the Judge shall sit upon his Seat,
To Execute his Judgments all compleat,
Then all the Nations gathered shall be,
And every Eye this righteous Judge shall see:
But he will them again all separate,
And then to cry, Lord, Lord, 'twill be too late.
He will set all the Saints on his Right-hand,
And at his Left the Reprobate shall stand:
Immediately the Sentence will be given,
That all the Saints shall enter into Heaven,
And with Salvation they shall Crowned be,
And Live with Christ to all Eternity.
The Reprobates then they will trembling stand,
Ready to be thrust from the Lord's Left-hand;
For they shall all be Sentenced to Hell,
With damned Spirits ever for to dwell,
Where they shall evermore both weep and wail;
But yet, alas, nothing will then prevail:
They shall be sent away too with a Curse;
There is no Sorrow ever can be worse.

div.head: A Meditation on the 5th. of Luke.

lg.l: OUR Lord and Saviour did fore tell
the happiness of those,
That his Commandments do love well,
and with his Gospel close.
The Poor in Spirit God will bless;
their Ransom Christ has paid,
And they his Kingdom shall possess
when they in Grave are laid:
Then all ye mourning Israel,
ye comforted shall be,
When you in Paradice shall dwell,
each one in his degree.
The Meek and Lowly shall Inherit
the Earth, and shall be fed;
When proud and wicked lofty Spirits
shall want their daily Bread.
Those that both Thirst and Hunger do
after God's Righteousness,
They shall be Fill'd and Cloathed too,
with Heaven's Happiness.
Ye Pure in Heart, which God shall see
his Glory all divine;
A glimpse of his pure Righteousness.
will make thee for to shine.
The Peace-makers are Stil'd you see,
the Children of their God:
No greater Title there c • n be
in all the World abroad.
All ye that Persecuted are
for Christ's Righteousness sake;
Ye need not fear, of Heaven's share
e'er long you shall partake.
Blessed be ye Reviled ones
whom Men do Vilifie;
Although they make your very Bones
within the Fire to fry,
If that it be for Jesus sake,
be glad and eke rejoyce;
For he of you will surely make
his treasure and his choice.
The Merciful that Mercy show,
they Mercy shall obtain,
And Mercy they shall find also
when Christ does come again.
And now ye Blessed ones, I say,
rejoyce all in the Lord;
Sing Praises to his Name alway,
for He's your great Reward.

div.head: A Meditation upon New-Years-Day, 1699.

lg.l: LOrd, if I may Live one Year more,
then let me Live to thee:
Let me not Live as heretofore,
in mine Iniquity:
For I have Lived hitherto,
always provoking thee,
Which hath fille • my Soul with wo,
and often troubled me.
After the Flesh I would not Live
here for to see Corruption:
Neither my self I would not give
to Live in high Voluption.
I fain would Live after the Spirit,
and give to God due Praise,
Eternal Life for to Inherit,
and Live with him always.
The wicked Live in pleasure here,
and wantonness also;
The Lord of Hosts they do not fear,
nor him desire to know.
But I would Live more Righteously,
here in this present World,
And when my end is come, that I
may not in it be hurl'd:
Also from sinful evil Thoughts
I fain would cleansed be;
For it upon my Soul has brought.
guilt in a high degree:
Therefore, good Lord, some pitty take,
or else I am undone,
And cleanse me for the Merits sake
of thy beloved Son.
Oh wash me in the Fountain clear,
which open stands for all:
In whom thy Spirit worketh here,
those thou art pleas'd to call.
Lord hear my sad complaint and moan
I often make to thee:
My Sin doth often make me groan,
a burden 'tis to me.
Oh let not Sin in me prevail,
for I am heavy-lade,
Lest that the Spirit it should fail,
and Soul which thou hast made.

div.head: More Meditations Composed into a Dialogue between the Holy-Spirit, and a dejected Soul.

lg.l: POor drooping Soul, why dost thou lye
oppressed thus with grief?
There was a Saviour once did die,
to give to thee Relief.
But my Corruptions often do
my tim'rous Soul affright;
My ghostly Enemies also,
say on with force and might:
To wound my tired Soul, so weak,
they do their best endeavour,
And fain would me a Prisoner make
in their black gulph for ever.
Is there any relief for me,
that so surrounded am?
Oh, that I but a place could see,
to hide my self from them!
There is a Rock of Age and Might,
a great and lofty King,
With thy great Enemies can fight,
and kill thy in-born Sin.
May such a worthless Soul as I
find Favour with this King,
That so doth grieve continually,
and load me with my Sin.
Come, rouse thy dull and sluggish Soul,
filled with fear and doubt;
Make haste I say, do not delay,
Christ holds his Scepter out.
Ah! blessed Spirit, is it so?
then I to him will go,
And beg the Pardon of my Sin,
and at his Feet lye low:
And then I will hold out my hand,
if Christ will take me up,
And make me on my Feet to stand,
and fill my Soul with Hope.
Now, with a holy boldness, I
thy Scepter, Lord, do crave:
O give it to me speedily,
for I it fain would have.

div.head: A Dialogue between Death, and a stout carnal Secure Sinner.

lg.l: COme thou stout Sinner, prepare to go with me
For I am come in hast to Summons thee
Before the great Tribunal to appear,
And there thy final Judgement thou shalt hear.
Hold! stay, I know not what thou art, nor who;
Therefore in plain I will not with thee go;
For I have other business in the way;
Therefore to talk with thee I cannot stay.
But yet I do demand of thee thy name,
And what thou art, also from whence thou came?
If thou desirest for to know my name;
And what I am also, from whence I came;
I do declare to thee, my name is Death,
And now am come for to demand thy breath.
I am a messenger, God sent me forth
To warn all Sinners to escape his wrath;
And I am come to do his will and pleasure;
Therefore I will no long wait thy leisure.
Death thou mistakes, I now am stout and strong,
Get thee to Age thou must not nature wrong;
For I am Young, and Brisk, and in my Prime,
And have not lived yet out half my time,
Do not thou boast of thy great strength and Youth,
For I do now tell thee the very truth,
I'll give thee such a stroak shall make thee reel,
And thou this day shalt my strong lashes feel,
I Strength and Power have to conquer all
Which on the Earth have lived since the fall.
Oh Death! do not so cruel be to Day;
To take from me my precious life away!
Oh Spare me yet a little time, for why
I am not yet prepared now to die,
Then blame thy self, but lay no blame to me,
Have I not warning often gave to thee?
Even the Head-ach, Heart-ach, and the Gout,
Because thou shouldst in time for me look out:
And make thy Calling and Election sure,
While oftentimes I passed by thy door,
But now it is too late, here is my Dart,
This very night shall pierce thee to the heart.
Delay no time, for go with me thou must,
Now I am come to turn thee into dust,
Thy date is out, thy Glass is near out run,
Unto thy Center therefore, now return.
What is my date quite out, my Glass near run?
Then wo is me that ever it begun!
Indeed I find my Breath is almost spent,
And tis to late for me now to Repent
Of any of my Sins I have commited,
For I of them shall never be acquited:
I feel in Head, and Heart, and every Vein
Horrour, and Grief, and sore tormenting Pain;
My trembling Soul is taking of her flight:
Alas, my Day is turned into Night!

sp.speaker: Spectator
sp.l: The Soul is Fled, the Body's turn'd to Clay,
And Death has done his Work and Gone his way.

div.head: A Dialogue between Death, and a Soul which fears not Death; but desires to be dissolved, and to be with Christ.

lg.l: HArk! who is this that knocketh at my door?
If it be Death, whom I have waited for:
Then why dost thou not unto me draw near?
For I of thee do not much stand in fear.
I fear thee not, thou canst do me no wrong,
Thou wilt but send me from the Earth, along
Unto my Home, where I desire to be:
Come Death, and do thy Office unto me?
For I have longed for my Dissolution:
Therefore draw near, and do the Execution:
Compleat thy Work I pray thee, speedily,
And do not keep me long in misery!
Come, weary Soul, which say'st thou dost not fear me,
Is not my ghastly looks enough to scare thee,
Which makes all Flesh on Earth to shake and quiver
When as I strike my dart into their Liver.
Hast thou got Faith enough to bear thee up?
To taste of Death, it is a bitter Cup;
Or hast thou some Vain hope to comfort thee?
If so, then I the same shall quickly see.
My Sting, which is thy Sin original,
Shall cut thee off when that on thee doth fall:
Therefore be careful now, and stand thy ground,
Or else my Sting may give a deadly wound.
This cannot be, since Christ my glorious King
Has said to thee, Oh Death! where is thy Sting?
And to the Grave, where is thy Victory?
Thy Sting, nor Grave, shall have no power on me.
I tell thee Death, when thou hast done thy worst,
Thou canst but lay my Body in the Dust
Until the glorious Resurrection-day,
When Imperfection shall be done away.
My God and King this Body then will raise,
And I shall Sing his Everlasting Praise:
His Grace and Love will then extended be:
But not for any good there is in me:
But for the Merit of his only Son,
The mighty God this good for me hath done.
What, shall I strike the stroke, and go my way?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Strike now with speed, and do not thou delay?

sp.speaker: Spectator.
sp.l: The Soul is Fled, the Body's turn'd to Dust,
Until the Resurrection of the Just.

div.head: A Dialogue between Christ the mighty King, and a Believer.

lg.l: MY Lord thou art a lofty King 'tis known,
Thou rul'st in Heav'n & Earth, and thereis none
Which can the Scepter take out of thy hand,
Thou mak'st all People bow at thy command.
Thou art the King of Kings, a King Peculiar;
Thou art the Lord of Lords, and Princes Ruler;
Thou settest up, again thou pullest down
Great Monarchies, which are of high Renown,
My Sov'reign Lord some things I fain would know,
If that it be thy pleasure me to show.
Speak forth thy mind, poor dust and clay, to me;
For liberty I freely give to thee:
With Men that are but dust, I do delight
To talk with them, if humble in my sight.
Thou art a King, most plain it doth appear
By thy great Works, and providential care:
But oh, how little does stout Sinners fear,
When of thy mighty Wonders they do hear?
But that which makes me to admire more,
Thou being such a King, becam'st so Poor;
For in the Holy-Scripture we do read,
Thou had'st not whereon for to lay thy head.
Althô I am a Prince of high Renown,
I did not come to Lodge on Beds of down;
Nor yet with Dainties up my self to fill;
But I did come to do my Father's Will.
It was my Father's Will to lay on me
Those miseries which did belong to thee;
I at his hand imbrac'd it willingly,
That thy poor Soul may live Eternally.
Lord shall thy Worm again once more presume
To speak unto thy Majesty supream:
Another thing I also call to mind,
Thy two Disciples thou didst send, to find
An Ass and Colt which was together ty'd,
Whereon thy glorious Majesty must Ride
Into the City of Jerusalem,
Thy kingly Office there for to proclaim.
Was that a Beast for such a glorious King
To set upon? I marvel at this thing.
The Beast I sat upon pleased me well;
I then that place of Scripture did fulfil
Isaiah's Prophecy must come to pass,
Great Sion's King must sit upon an Ass.
Lowly and Meek this Scripture I fulfils,
Althô the Cattel on a thousand Hills
Were all My Father's, yet I would have none
But my poor Asses Colt to ride upon.
Lord, may I speak again, and not offend,
And shall thy blessed Ear to me attend?
Speak on thy mind to me, and nothing fear;
For I am ready still to lend an Ear.
When that great Caesar, which was called King,
Did give command his Tribute to bring in;
Lord, why did'st thou abase thy self so low
As to bid one of thy Disciples, go
Unto a Fish to take a piece of Coin,
When all the Treasure of the Earth was thine?
'Twas for my Elect's sake I stoop't so low,
When my Disciple I did bid to go
Unto the Fish to take a piece of Coin,
Also to show a Miracle divine.
And that my Peter should confirmed be,
When such a Miracle was wrought by me:
I gave to Caesar that which was his Right;
Do thou do so 'tis pleasing in my sight.
Lord, suffer me thy dust and ashes poor
To ask of thee but this one question more:
What was the cause, Lord, that thou thought'st it meet
To wash & cleanse thy own Disciple's Feet,
When they should have attended all on thee,
As other Princes they attended be?
Such washings thou must daily of me crave;
For them I wash I purpose for to Save;
But if thou wilt not washt and cleansed be,
Assure thy self thou hast no part in me.
Such washings Lord, do not to me deny;
Such washings Lord, let me have speedily.
If thou by Faith such washings of me crave,
Such washings of me thou shalt surely have;
And what thou dost desire more to know,
My Holy Scripture will unto thee show;
Go search them daily, there thou may'st it see,
That they are they which testify of me.
There thou may'st hear of my Humiliation,
Also again of my great Exaltation;
Which shows my kingly Office unto all,
Likewise my Priestly, and Prophetical.
A good Example I have been to thee;
Therefore take heed, and do thou learn by me:
I was a Pattern of Humility.
As for stout Sinners which of my wonders hear,
And do not of me greatly stand in fear;
The time will come when all such fearless ones
Shall filled be with fearf • l Sighs and Grones.
Come, do not thou so curiously inquire;
But have a care, do not too high aspire
Into the Myst'ries of my sacred Will,
Least thou thy Palsy-brain dost over-fill:
But see thou Justice do, and Mercy love,
And walk thou humbly with thy God above;
Then thou shalt have the benefit of all
My Sufferings which on me hear did fall.
My Sov'reign Lord, I am a Sinner vild,
And my presumptious Heart has me beguil'd:
I spoken have, but I will not proceed;
Lord Pardon me this my presumptious deed.
My Hand upon my Mouth, I now will lay;
My Mouth into the Dust, no more to say;
Yet still an Int'rest Lord, I crave in thee,
And into Judgment enter not with me.
