div.head: A Spiritual Meditation upon a Bee.

lg.l: MY Soul like to a little painful Bee
To build her Combs in Jesus Chyrist doth flee,
And if she willing is to live and thrive,
Then she must haste, and get into her Hive:
Because her Hive is in a Garden fair,
Wherein she gather may, and never spare,
Of Blossoms sweet, and Flowers fragrant;
There is enough to give her full content.
My Bee with Honey there may fill her Combs,
To keep her in the windy Winter-storms:
Because in Winter forth she cannot go,
By reason of the pinching Frost and Snow:
But when the Sumner-season is come in,
My little painful Bee is on the Wing;
Abroad she Flys then with a • oyful mind,
To work on each sweet Blossom she can find.
Over the sweetest Flower she will hover,
And there she will her painfulness discover;
And when she's Load, she to her Hive will hye,
To Treasure up her Lading Joyfully,
To fill her Combs against the time of need,
That she upon her Honey then may feed;
But if my Bee a Shower should espy,
Into her Hive away then she must hye;
For if that she doth long the time delay,
The Rain may drive my Bee out of her way;
But while my painful Bee, she is at work,
The Hornet and the Whasp for her doth lurk,
To catch my Bee, her Honey for to take,
And then of my poor Bee a prey to make:
But if my Bee she should become a drone,
My Bee will quickly then be left alone.
Out of the Hive forthwith they will her beat,
Because their Honey she no more shall Eat;
And of her Life they soon will her bereave,
Because with them she shall no more receive;
For while they laboured to fill each Comb,
She lost her Sting, and so became a drone:
Therefore, my Soul, do not to sloath incline;
But Labour now, the precious time is thine;
For if thou should'st be sluggish, and delay,
Then wo will be to thee another day:
Labour therefore, to get in Christ, thy Hive;
There's Honey store, which will keep thee alive:
And be not thou like to the idle drones,
Which lye and languish in their empty Combs;
Take care in building, 'tis a curious Art,
In building Combs, each Bee to have his part;
And do not build thy Combs confusedly,
If thou dost build with Hay, Wood, or with Stubble,
It will bring thee into confused trouble:
But unto higher things thou must aspire;
For that is Fuel sit but for the Fire.

div.head: The Author's Request.
div.l: THE Stock of Honey now for which I trade,
Oh that it may unto me so be made,
Like to the increase of the Widdow's Oyl,
Which in the Widdow's Vessel ne'er did fail
Until that she in full her debts had paid,
As it is in the Holy-Scripture said.

div.head: A Meditation Composed into an Hymn of Mortality.

lg.l: MAn's Life it like a Shaddow is
that soon away doth fly;
That we may know assuredly,
all Flesh is born to die.
We are compared to the Grass,
our Substance is so brittle;
Or like the running of a Race;
or like a Weaver's Shuttle:
And as a Taper that is lighted,
full soon doth waste away;
Or like a Traveller benighted,
who can no longer stay.
Our mould'ring Bodies well they may
be termed to a Flower,
Which in the Morning's fresh and gay,
and cropt within an Hour
Oh, thou poor weak and feeble Man,
why dost thou lofty look?
Thy Life is like a measur'd span,
or bubble in the Brook.
Therefore let all, both great and small,
prepare for Death, I say;
Before into the silent Pit
it Summons you away.
When Death shall strike the Fatal blow,
who can him then with-stand?
No pitty he did ever show,
either by Sea or Land.
You must comply, as well as I,
when Death his S the does whet,
To mow you down unto the ground,
wherein you must be shut.

div.head: Word by way of Caution to the Female-Sex.

lg.l: YE Female-Sex, Do you believe,
when first the World began,
That God immortal Souls did give
to you, as well as Man?
Do you believe that God did make
both Sex upright to stand?
Do you believe that both did break
God's great and strict command?
If so, then how can we expect
favour with God to find,
If that we do his Word reject,
and cast it out of mind?
Do you imagine to escape,
or that you shall go clear,
And that before God's Judgment seat
you never shall appear?
If so, then after Godliness
you need not make such hast;
And as for seeking Holiness,
let that alone till last:
But oh, do not your selves decieve,
Satan to gratify,
Least that you do your Souls bereave
of blest Felicity.
Virgins and Wives, I write these Lines to you
In Christian-love, and so Farewell, Adieu.

div.head: A Meditation on the World's Deceitfulness, and the Vanity of Man's craving Heart.

lg.l: THE Heart of Man it is Triangle:
the World is round you see:
Therefore the 〈◊〉 with all the World
will not contented be:
For take the World, then if you can,
and put in the Triangle,
I mean, into the Heart of Man,
and yet he still will wrangle.
See here's a Globe, the World's a Ball,
in this Triangle p t,
And still the Heart for more will call,
it wants a filling up.
Then since the World unto thy Heart
can give no true content,
Why dost thou grieve when she does part,
and after her Lament?
Tush, let her go, she is a cheat
unto the Heart of Man;
Although she seemeth to be sweet,
dis-prove it if you can.
She'll sing to thee sweet Lulla-by,
whilst that thou dost her keep:
But when she takes her wings to fly,
will trouble on thee heap:
Then put no Confidence in her;
for she is but a Thief:
She'll rob thee of true comforts here,
and leave thee full of grief.
To day she charms thee with her Smiles,
and Frowns on thee to morrow:
She with her wiles, thy Heart beguiles,
and pierces it with sorrow.
Trust not in Smiles, nor fear her Frowns;
but trust in God alone:
Fear him in whom true Joys abounds,
for the World yieldeth none.
My Brethren dear, do you take care,
when you look in this Book,
And pray the World may not insnare
you with her Bait and Hook.
THere is a little Book sent forth,
which is not all my own:
Some others added unto it,
which Book I do not own.
Although 'tis Publisht in my Name,
and sent unto your View:
But the Addition to the same,
I little of it knew.
